document.masterDocTitle: Pamphagidae (Orthoptera: Acridoidea) from the Palaearctic Region: taxonomy, classification, keys to genera and a review of the tribe Nocarodeini I. Bolívar

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Pamphagidae (Orthoptera: Acridoidea) from the Palaearctic Region: taxonomy, classification, keys to genera and a review of the tribe Nocarodeini I. Bolívar

subSubSection.paragraph: Type locality. Turkey: Konya, Akşehir. Holotype: male (Unspecified host).

Distribution. Known from western Turkey : Mainly in the eastern half of
Aegean Region
along the mountains of the inner
Aegean Region
, Kütahya , Eskişehir , Konya , Uşak , Afyonkarahisar and the northern parts of Isparta , Burdur , Antalya and Denizli provinces ( Fig. 840 ).

Remarks. This species was described by Demirsoy (1973) as the type species of
Pseudosavalania Demirsoy
(now a syn. of
Paranocarodes
). It is very similar to
P. fieberi
. Actually the only difference from it, is the absence of tympanum. Ramme (1951) described this species previously as
Paranocarodes atympanicus
after 2 females, one in the NHMUK and the other in the MfN. Ramme preferred to select the holotype preserved in his collection of the MfN. However, while the holotype of
P. atympanicus
is a female nymph of
P. tolunayi
, the paratype (adult female) belongs to this species. Therefore
P. atympanicus Ramme, 1951
is a synonym of
P. tolunayi tolunayi Ramme, 1949
and
P. karabagi ( Demirsoy, 1973 )
is a valid species (see
P. tolunayi tolunayi
below).

The main character of this species is the absence of tympanum. While Ramme (1951) considered that this character is specific, Demirsoy (1973) thought of it as a genus character. This species is undoubtedly a member of
Paranocarodes
. The reduction stages of tympanum are also variable in
Nocaracris
which is not a generic character alone particularly for the Anatolian taxa (see also the genus
Nocaracris
and the Remarks section of the tribe Nocarodeini ).
